It is thought by the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs that it would be desirable to inform before-hand the French Italian and United States Governments of the condition we intend to attaoh to British recognition of Danish Sovereignty over Greenland. Italian Ambassador has in fact enquired as to attitude of His Majesty's Government in regard to Danish request. Having thus warned these Governments the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs would propose to inform the Danish Minister that the geographical position of Greenland makes question of its territorial ownership a matter of great importance to British Empire as a whole and to Canada in particular but that His Majesty's Government would have no objection to recognising Danish Sovereignty over whole of Greenland provided that in the event of Denmark wishing to dispose of the territory she is prepared to grant right of pr exemptionpossible views of your Ministers on this proposal.(Sent 7,5 p.m. 3rd May, 1920.)to British Empire. (Received Colonial Office 7.20 a.m. 7th Hay, 1920).Fay 6th. British recognition of Danish sovereignty over Greenland. The course of action proposed by Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs as indicated in your telegram of Fay 3rd meets with concurrence of Canadian Government.
